text: they may have said goodbye lenin in kiev
a symbolic break for the past but in
eastern Ukraine the famous Russian
revolutionary is standing tall in the
city of Lugansk there are lots of
Lenin's but no barricades no protest
camps Russia is close by the European
Union feels very distant ask Valentina
what she thinks of pro-europe protesters
in the capital and you'll hear nothing
but criticism she fears that closer ties
with the EU would put up prices and make
her life harder the rocky boy through
the right those protesters are fools if
I was the president I would chase them
off the square then I would unite
Ukraine with Russia and with Putin the
EU just milk us for all we've got we'd
get nothing in return across town at the
locomotive battery they too are looking
east not west
I'll be surprising when you consider who
buys all their trains for us at the
Russian market is the key market and the
only market we have this latest moment
one arm percent of our production goes
directly to Russia it's here in eastern
Ukraine that you'll find the country's
main industries its biggest factories
some of them so big in fact they're like
cities within a city traditionally
Russia has been their main market and
that's why people here don't want to
damage those economic ties with moscow
that's why the City Council has been
recruiting residents to go to Kiev to
support President Yanukovych and to stop
what they see as a euro coupe enough
mushy but some of the stakes are high
the mayor warns that Ukraine could split
into two countries women are so my first
not perfect my biggest fear is that in a
year or so I'll need a passport to
travel to Western Ukraine to visit the
graves of my parents there are forces at
work trying to divide this country
between east and west
Ukraine continues to be pulled in two
directions so far independent square has
been the focus of attention now the east
once its voice heard Steve Rosenberg BBC
News Lugansk
